text: The Hermit (Il solitario) The Hermit (Il solitario) is a 1908 painting by John Singer Sargent. It is part of the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.The Hermit (Il solitario) at the Metropolitan Museum of Art ==Description== The painting was the result of sketches Sargent made in the Aosta Valley, in the foothills of the Italian Alps. He uses textured brushstrokes to convey the dappled sunlight falling on the forest, the hermit, and two deer. Despite the similarity with depictions of Saint Jerome in the wilderness, Sargent wrote to the director of the Metropolitan, "I wish there were another simple word [other than Hermit] that did not bring with it any Christian association, and that rather suggested quietness and pantheism." ==References== Category:1908 paintings Category:Paintings by John Singer Sargent Category:Paintings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art Category:Deer in art
